title: Euler-Lagrange Equation
subtitle: Complete Derivation from Calculus of Variations
description: Derive the Euler-Lagrange equation from first principles using the calculus of variations to find paths that minimize functionals.

steps.title: 1.1 What is a Functional?
steps.explanation: A functional maps functions to real numbers. We seek the function y(x) that minimizes J

steps.title: 1.2 The Variational Problem
steps.explanation: We want to find y(x) that makes J stationary (usually a minimum) with boundary conditions y(a) = y_a and y(b) = y_b

steps.title: 2.1 Introducing a Small Variation
steps.explanation: Consider a small perturbation η(x) to the optimal path

steps.title: 2.2 Properties of the Variation
steps.explanation: The variation must vanish at the boundaries

steps.title: 2.3 The Perturbed Functional
steps.explanation: Express J as a function of ε

steps.title: 3.2 Multivariable Chain Rule
steps.explanation: For L = L(x, u(ε), v(ε)) with u = y + εη and v = y' + εη', apply the chain rule

steps.title: 3.3 Computing the Derivatives
steps.explanation: Calculate the derivatives of u and v with respect to ε

steps.title: 3.4 Derivative of L with Respect to ε
steps.explanation: Substitute the derivatives into the chain rule

steps.title: 3.5 Evaluate at ε = 0
steps.explanation: At ε = 0, we have u = y and v = y', so

steps.title: 3.6 Taylor Expansion of L(ε)
steps.explanation: Using the generic Taylor formula, expand L around ε = 0
equation: L(x, y + \epsilon \eta, y' + \epsilon \eta') \approx L(x, y, y') + \epsilon \left( \frac{\partial L}{\partial y} \eta + \frac{\partial L}{\partial y'} \eta' \right) + O(\epsilon^2)

steps.title: 3.7 Expansion of J(ε)
steps.explanation: Substitute the Taylor expansion of L into the functional J

steps.title: 3.8 Integrating the Taylor Expansion
steps.explanation: Distribute the integral over the Taylor series terms
equation: J(\epsilon) \approx \int_a^b L(x, y, y') \, dx + \epsilon \int_a^b \left( \frac{\partial L}{\partial y} \eta + \frac{\partial L}{\partial y'} \eta' \right) dx + O(\epsilon^2)

steps.title: 3.9 Defining the First Variation
steps.explanation: Express J(ε) in terms of J(0) and the first variation δJ
equation: \text{where } \delta J = \int_a^b \left( \frac{\partial L}{\partial y} \eta + \frac{\partial L}{\partial y'} \eta' \right) dx

steps.title: 4.1 Condition for Stationarity
steps.explanation: For J to be stationary (minimum, maximum, or saddle point) at ε = 0, the first derivative must vanish

steps.title: 4.2 Setting the First Variation to Zero
steps.explanation: From our Taylor expansion, dJ/dε|_{ε=0} equals δJ, so the first variation must vanish for all η
equation: \delta J = \int_a^b \left( \frac{\partial L}{\partial y} \eta + \frac{\partial L}{\partial y'} \eta' \right) dx = 0

steps.title: 4.3 Arbitrary Variation Requirement
steps.explanation: This condition must hold for all admissible variations η(x) that satisfy the boundary conditions

steps.title: 5.1 Integration by Parts Formula
steps.explanation: We need to eliminate η' by integrating by parts

steps.title: 5.2 Applying Integration by Parts
steps.explanation: Apply to the second term with u = ∂L/∂y' and dv = η' dx
equation: \int_a^b \frac{\partial L}{\partial y'} \eta' \, dx = \left[\frac{\partial L}{\partial y'} \eta\right]_a^b - \int_a^b \eta \frac{d}{dx}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial y'}\right) dx

steps.title: 5.3 Using Boundary Conditions
steps.explanation: The boundary term vanishes since η(a) = η(b) = 0

steps.title: 5.4 Substituting Back
steps.explanation: Replace in the variation equation
equation: \int_a^b \eta\frac{\partial L}{\partial y} \, dx - \int_a^b \eta \frac{d}{dx}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial y'}\right) dx = 0

steps.title: 6.1 Factoring Out η
steps.explanation: Combine the integrals

steps.title: 6.2 The Fundamental Lemma
steps.explanation: Since η(x) is arbitrary (except at boundaries), the integrand must be zero

steps.title: 6.3 The Euler-Lagrange Equation
steps.explanation: The fundamental equation of the calculus of variations

steps.title: 7.1 Multiple Variables Form
steps.explanation: For functionals with multiple dependent variables
equation: J = \int_a^b L(x, y_1, y_2, \ldots, y_n, y_1', y_2', \ldots, y_n') \, dx
\frac{d}{dx}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial y_i'}\right) - \frac{\partial L}{\partial y_i} = 0, \quad i = 1, 2, \ldots, n

steps.title: 7.2 Higher Derivatives Form
steps.explanation: When L depends on higher derivatives
equation: J = \int_a^b L(x, y, y', y'') \, dx
\frac{\partial L}{\partial y} - \frac{d}{dx}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial y'}\right) + \frac{d^2}{dx^2}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial y''}\right) = 0

steps.title: 7.3 Expanded Derivative Form
steps.explanation: Expanding the total derivative using the chain rule
equation: \frac{d}{dx}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial y'}\right) = \frac{\partial^2 L}{\partial x \partial y'} + \frac{\partial^2 L}{\partial y \partial y'}y' + \frac{\partial^2 L}{\partial y'^2}y''
